comments.commentBody:
I am a small rancher with a herd of less than 100 cows that eats grass year-round. We add hay and liquid feed (protein and minerals/vits) in the winter only to supplement the dimiished forage quality to keep the herd and baby calves healthy. We depend upon antibiotics when animals are injured or unhealthy, and we diligently conform to the labels that prescribe purpose for use and dosage based upon weight. Ranchers don't abuse drugs, as it takes considerable effort to bring the cattle into the barnyard for treatment and drugs are costly.

There are not enough vetereinarians specializing in livestock in the US. The livestock industry is seriously recruiting students. There aren't enough vets to make a ranch visits for every call to treat simple pink eye; or to drive an hour or more to the ranch to prescribe penicillin for a wound.

One of my concerns is that animal welfare will be compromised by the unavailability of prompt veterinary response and prescriptions. Ranchers know that prompt treatment alleviates pain and stimulates healing, which we desire. How long will it be reasonable for us to wait for the vet to answer the phone? To drive to the ranch when they can get to it? We're all experienced at reading labels and giving shots, and we have a vet-patient relationship. Most of us follow Beef Quality Assurance training and guidelines.

Martha Coakley was a poor candidate, not on grounds of personality, but because she ran a campaign that was not energetic and did not respond to Tea Party fervor. Also, in that election, as in the last midterms generally, many progressive voters stayed home, but that is a discussion in itself.

MD's posts seem frenzied, as if David, by celebrating Massachusetts' traditions of intellect was making an affront to New York. As a native New Yorker (the city, no less), long resident in Massachusetts, with deep and continuing personal and family ties to both states, I find MD's thread needlessly digressive, bizarre, and a bit silly.

I doubt that it will be necessary for MD (and anyone else included in the "we all" for whom he/she is spokesperson) to hold the breath longer than November to be reassured that Massachusetts has come to its senses. Any momentary lapse of sanity -- and please, not all of us lost so much sense so as to vote for a Republican -- will be compensated for by an extraordinary new US Senator.

If this answer does not satisfy MD, and an apology from Massachusetts for electing Scott Brown is required, on behalf of the Commonwealth I humbly apologize and promise that it won't happen again. Now, go send a big contribution to Elizabeth Warren.

I was under the impression that once someone filed for bankruptcy, they were not able to do so again for some time.  Therefore there was no way they could default on a loan offered to them and therefore they were actually ideal targets for people lending money.  A no, or at least minimal, risk situation.  If this is the case it makes perfect sense to me why these people are being offered loans.  The article does not seem to mention this.  Is this accurate or no?

Mr. Romney, the apparent nominee and front man for the Republican party is just voicing what is common thought among the Republicans I know in my very red state, namely the very  conservative right wing of the party, mostly men, should  chose what is best for women.  The corollary is that they believe women should not or do not want to make their own choices.  Women will make a choice and it will not be to turn back the clock.  The actions of various Republican legislatures around the country are speaking to women louder than any soothing words that could be used by Mr. Romney.
Which is why they only will give a fifth round pick. Not much to lose and plenty of upside.
Something tells me that at this point in his career, the odds of him being an impact starter are low. Teams don't give away starting linebackers in return for a 5th round pick for no reason.

Paul:

It's widely known that Olympics cause more trouble/ cost more money than they're worth. As should be apparent, I'm not arguing that the Olympics should have gone to NYC. Rather, that the context in which the WSS arose is totally distinct from the notion of a Pier 40 arena. Whereas a WSS would have served a Jets/ Olympics combo, this Pier 40 plan would serve only a non-existent franchise and ClearWindow/ TIAS's 2+ year campaign while drastically altering the current use.

It's little surprise the stadium proposal leans strongly towards Queens/ Flushing/ Willets Point.

Asto NJ: you brought it up in an effort to tell me to butt out. As if that's an argument. Your present connection to NJ is tenuous, but I've not asked you to but out. You are clearly an ally in the struggle against irrational fiscal policies and real estate hokum boondoggles.

That is, until it's one you seem to support.

Clear: You seem to be the snippiest of the bunch. How quaint that you (also) personalize your attacks on those who doubt the plan. And how revealing.

I simply think the idea of a Pier 40 stadium is weak, the transportation burden substantial, and the neighborhood impact a palpable reality. Etc etc

If you authored the plan on TIAS, your rose-colored responses there two years ago seem only to have turned more sour and mean-spirited. At least Paul tried to be polite in telling me to stuff it.

I will not address your presumptions and accusations. Conclude any way you want. That's probably better than asking.

Hey, Guys, get a grip.  Were the 4 brutes top-level recruits?  Are they important to CSU wining football games? If so, you have  NO CASE, and they will be suspended, but very quietly re-instated on the team this summer - just in time for pre-season practice. UGH!  Yo reep what you sow when you want to go Big-Time Football. Rapes, assaults, beatings of all kinds are sure to follow.

As an NYC expat living near Boston, the system here they call the "T" is old, slow and you can't get there from here. I actually revel in the convenience of the subway and bus system of the MTA when I am in New York. This may be Red Sox nation but to me it is a place too far from my beloved Mets ball club, opera and museum.
Ya gotta love it's convenience and the price if right. Go Mets, go NYTA
Fugetaboutit

A scintillating, inspiring piece by two Times pros whose images and words are always a treat. This piece could not have come at a better moment. One hopes it harmonizes discordant voices around the country. Bravo!
And that's all determined from this little article? Bravo!   Take another look at the backgrounds and pictures. surely you will see that is not the case at all.

These are not the typical American girls. These are pampered and over indulged kids with no sense of reality.... An extension of their parents.

Nicely exposed photographs from a technical point of view.

The images Ms. Szwarc has created are pure fine art, and should be contemplated as such. I hope to see them at the galleries and museums one day. Great work, pure at its core and extremely touching. I bow to the Artist.

OK, you made a choice and feel righteous about it. Fine. Next pregnancy, maybe you will be asked not to go to restaurants, leave the house, wear tight clothes, be around people who aren't supportive, etc. Will you still feel OK with  it then? how about no flying, no driving, no walking. Where do you draw the line?

@ John Beaty: During my pregnancies, I engaged in moderate exercise, abstained from coffee, alcohol and raw fish, rested alot (was lucky that I could).  I wasn't comfortable flying, so I didn't.  I came under enormous pressure from relatives due to that. I am not touting my 'sacrifice' (generally, it was a restful, pleasant time), but why do you have to be so judgemental?  The point is that every woman has to decide for herself!

I easily gave up my vices, coffee and wine, with both of my pregnancies.  I found abstaining from sushi to be more difficult than avoiding alcohol.  Nine months is a very short period of time so the sacrifices made are swift and not so memorable, really.  I would give it all up again.

PINE TAR on the outside and cork on the inside? Here I thought that bats were just carved chunks of wood!

What about cricket bats?

DeadlineL @12:14 p.m. A corked bat in the vernacular, is not exactly 'cricket' but Sosa and his ilk knew that!

Howie

leapfinger - One corks a bat by drilling a hold several inches down the center of the barrel (thicker) end of the bat, filling it with cork and then plugging the top of the hole so that it can't be detected.

What it accomplishes is that it makes the bat a little bit lighter without changing it's overall size, thus allowing the batter to swing it a little faster.

By the way, up until the late 1930's players typically used quite heavy bats, often well over 40 ounces, in the belief that the momentum provided by the heavier bat would allow them to hit the ball harder. Ted Williams was the first player to conclude that bat speed was more important than weight and started using much lighter weight bats, which eventually became the norm.

"Baseball has been BERI BERI good to me" Garrett Morris portraying Chico Esquela, on the original SNL!
For a THURXWDP this was relatively UZI and what are the ODES of that?
When there's no REBUS in sight, simply hail a cab!
ENNUI go to Friday!

Howie

Ralph --quite profound but your words sound all too familiar. That is because I SAID THEM. See below. DON'T PLAGIARIZE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! It is wrong on so many levels.

Art Guy
1 Fans
10:36 PM on 04/01/2012
Yes, the girls look serious, sad and even depressed. And yes, they are all holding their AG doll. Do you see the contradiction and tension the images create? This is what a good artists, writers, and actors try to do. That's right-create some tension. If the image is what you "expect" it tobe, then you would not take the time to think about it and comment on it. Illona Szwarc is a genius. Remember her name because you will see her again.
Favorite (0)

See the comments at the end of this link:http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/03/26/ilona-szwarc-american-girl-doll...

Yes, the girls look serious, sad and even depressed. And yes, they are all holding their AG doll. Do you see the contradiction and tension the images create? This is what great artists, writers, and actors try to do. That's right: create some tension. If the image is what you "expect" it to be, then you would not take the time to think about it and comment on it. They are thought provoking images that should make you think. Illona Szwarc is a genius. Remember her name because you will see her again.

All still photographs are one moment in time. I don't think anyone should read too much into the photos. These are interesting posed portraits of girls with their American Girl dolls. This is not a sociological study.

At least the American Girl stories are tied to characters in different periods of American history. There is no mention of the books in this article. The characters in the books are portrayed as having interesting lives in those periods. Our daughter read the books but did not have a doll. She enjoyed the stories and learned some history. I made her an "colonial' dress, and she wore it on our tour of historic Williamsburg, VA. She imagined herself as the "colonial" girl in the story.

I grew up in the 1950s and 1960s when dolls were the main toys given to girls. My dolls were babies, brides and Barbie. These dolls presented a strong bias for society's acceptable options for women. The American Girl characters send a much better message about girls' lives in American history.
Well photographed, but for some reason, very chilling.

My childhood friends and I all had American Girl dolls--only one each, from the historical collection, and treasured. We were much younger than most of the girls in this set, though, and we stopped playing with our dolls around age 9 or 10. The historical collection dolls also all came with book sets and fewer clothing options, so our experience in the mid-90s was perhaps different.

The American Girl doll phenomenon is fascinating, though, in terms of how it has continued to evolve since the first dolls were introduced, and how the changes in the line can be seen as representing shifts in the way the parent company (although perhaps American culture more broadly) frames and understands "American-ness" and what it means to be, literally, an American girl.

Another byproduct I've experienced, as a boxum woman who is in the upper range of normal near the 'overweight' line - - I need to lose weight to deal with my insulin resistance. Getting closer to the middle of the normal range would help a lot.

But I don't mention my changes in food and exercise habits to hardly anyone. Why?

Because I'm tired of hearing "Oh, Banty, you're just *fine* the way you are!"

They think they're being all so supportive and being all so accepting, but I really don't want to get into all the why's and wherefore's. Who wants to explain health reasons, and there are a fair number of people who don't believe physicians' consensus on even that. So it's not really supportive now is it.

We need to emphasize *healthy*. And there's a decent range of weight that that encompasses.

Instead of "real women have curves," can we come up with something else that acknowleges all of our beautiful bodies? Like "real women just are"? I dunno. I'm certainly not as trim as I was pre-kids, but I'm not really all that curvy, either, and never was.

E - - how about "real women are healthy".

Or something like that.

I understand the need for women to make some social room for normal variation and the changes that come with children and time. But let's not normalize unhealth. (Or trivialize health either as just some blood numbers, when orthopedic problems loom.)

Some of us mothers DO still look like 12-year-old boys, never having quite gotten the genes together to join the "real women have curves" campaign.

I often get "I never would have guessed you had a baby!" or "You don't look like a mother at all." Sadly, these comments are well-meaning compliments. At this point I just sort of raise my eyebrows and stare until the other person starts to feel awkward, although I may start in with "Thanks... I certainly wouldn't want to look like a mother!"

"How do we help our teenage girls combat that?"

Shouldn't we expect the math teachers, instead of the teenage girls, to be fighting their bias?

A friend taught me to pull the tick backwards on itself and we get the whole tick out every time.  We've already pulled off 3 that had not yet bitten and one that got my husband who is now itching like crazy.  Not looking forward to this tick season of fury.

I have always loved math - and it is this love that my husband and I have always tried to convey to our children. Nighttime is for bedtime stories, but there is no fixed time for math - any time we see something interesting, or one of them is bored, we try to come up with little math puzzles and stories. For example, I was telling my 9 year old about why we use base 10 (10 fingers), and I began telling him about binary, and why that might be useful if you wanted to design a machine that did arithmetic (a switch can be on or off, 1 or 0). This led to explaining binary to him, and he was so thrilled with the fact that he had grasped the idea - all this without writing anything down.
For those who haven't already had the pleasure of reading it, I highly recommend the Steven Strogatz series on Elements of Math:
http://topics.nytimes.com/top/opinion/series/steven_strogatz_on_the_elem...

It worked wonderfully well on our foster daughter, who had had them for months, and me, when I got them from her.  Constant nit-picking and combing and would work temporarily lots of times, but the olive oil was the thing that finally worked.
Sorry;  I should have said it worked for lice, not ticks.

The mild winter and early spring we are having bodes poorly for the tick season. Already we have seen one on one of the dogs--we are in for a long season I'm afraid.

We don't have Lyme here, or other tick-borne diseases, but there are so many of them. Two years ago I was hoping to rely on hand picking I one day pulled 40 off the puppy. We now use collars that are for ticks only, as we have no problems with fleas.
